sentences.text: Snap election|Snap general elections were held in Ecuador on 20 August 2023 to elect the President of Ecuador, members of the National Assembly (Ecuador)|National Assembly, and to decide on two referendums. The elections were triggered by the invocation of {{Lang|es|muerte cruzada}}, which 2023 Ecuadorian political crisis|dissolved the National Assembly (Ecuador)|National Assembly on 17 May 2023. A run-off election was held on 15 October 2023 to elect the President after no candidate secured the required threshold to win in the first round. Incumbent president Guillermo Lasso was eligible for a second term, but he announced on 18 May that he would not seek re-election in response to his impeachment.

sentences.text: Advancing to the 15 October run-off, Luisa González of the Citizen Revolution Movement secured first place with 33% of the vote, while Daniel Noboa of the National Democratic Action (Ecuador)|National Democratic Action came in second with 24%. At 35 years old, he became the youngest president in Ecuador's history.

references.text: <ref name=WaPo/><ref name=reutersresults/> Noboa's second-place finish was considered surprising and an Upset (competition)#Politics|upset, with his debate performance seen as a key factor in his rise in popularity.<ref name=aol/> Noboa ultimately defeated González in the runoff election, securing 52% of the vote, a result similar to Guillermo Lasso's victory in 2021.<ref>{{cite news|title=Daniel Noboa, presidente electo de Ecuador con el 87% de actas escrutadas|url=https://www.metroecuador.com.ec/noticias/2023/10/16/daniel-noboa-el-presidente-electo-de-ecuador-con-el-87-de-actas-escrutadas/|access-date=15 October 2023|work=Metro Ecuador|date=15 October 2023|archive-date=16 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231016054017/https://www.metroecuador.com.ec/noticias/2023/10/16/daniel-noboa-el-presidente-electo-de-ecuador-con-el-87-de-actas-escrutadas/|url-status=live}}</ref>

On 17 May 2023, a day after he presented his defense in an impeachment process against him, President Lasso invoked the {{Lang|es|muerte cruzada}} mechanism provided for in Article 148 of the 2008 Constitution of Ecuador|2008 Constitution to 2023 Ecuadorian political crisis|dissolve the National Assembly (Ecuador)|National Assembly, bringing forward legislative and presidential elections.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|last=Valencia|first=Alexandra|date=17 May 2023|title=Ecuador president dissolves legislature, bringing elections forward|language=en |work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/ecuador-president-dissolves-legislature-bringing-elections-forward-2023-05-17/|access-date=17 May 2023|archive-date=18 May 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230518214809/https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/ecuador-president-dissolves-legislature-bringing-elections-forward-2023-05-17/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 18 May, Diana Atamaint, the president of the National Electoral Council (Ecuador)|National Electoral Council (CNE), announced 20 August 2023 as the tentative date for the legislative election and the first round of the presidential vote. The CNE had until 24 May to finalize the electoral calendar.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|title=CNE tiene el 20 de agosto como fecha tentativa para realizar las elecciones generales anticipadas |url=https://www.eluniverso.com/noticias/politica/cne-tiene-el-20-de-agosto-como-fecha-tentativa-para-realizar-las-elecciones-generales-anticipadas-nota/|access-date=18 May 2023|work=El Universo|date=18 May 2023|archive-date=18 May 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230518160951/https://www.eluniverso.com/noticias/politica/cne-tiene-el-20-de-agosto-como-fecha-tentativa-para-realizar-las-elecciones-generales-anticipadas-nota/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 13 June, Luisa González was en route to register her presidential candidacy with the National Electoral Council with her supporters and president of the Citizen Revolution movement, Marcela Aguiñaga, when they were attacked with pepper spray and tear gas by the National Police of Ecuador|National Police. She was treated at a Quito medical center after flushing her eyes from the pepper spray. The National Police claimed to have used chemical agents to protect security and public order because of the hostile behavior of González's supporters.

sentences.text: Less than two weeks before the election, on 9 August 2023, candidate Fernando Villavicencio was Assassination of Fernando Villavicencio|assassinated after a campaign rally in Quito at the age of 59. He is the first presidential candidate to have been assassinated in the country since Abdón Calderón Muñoz|Abdon Calderon Muñoz's assassination in 1978. The assassination of Villavicencio made international news, prompting condemnation of the attack and condolences by foreign countries as well as the Organization of American States, who called for an investigation. He was replaced on the ballot by a fellow journalist, Christian Zurita, keeping Villavicencio's running mate Andrea González.

sentences.text: The president is elected using a modified two-round system, with a candidate required to get over 50% of the vote, or get over 40% of the vote and be 10 points ahead of their nearest rival, to be elected in the first round.

references.text: <ref name="guide"/> The president is limited to two consecutive four-year terms.<ref name="guide">{{Cite web|url=https://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/2265/|title=IFES Election Guide | Elections: Ecuador Pres 2013|website=www.electionguide.org|access-date=23 June 2023|archive-date=31 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190331044326/http://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/2265/|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name="PDBA">{{Cite web|url=https://pdba.georgetown.edu/ElecSys/Ecuador/ecuador.html|title=Ecuador: Sistemas Electorales / Electoral Systems|website=pdba.georgetown.edu|access-date=23 June 2023|archive-date=19 April 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230419091911/https://pdba.georgetown.edu/ElecSys/Ecuador/ecuador.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Members of the National Assembly (Ecuador)|National Assembly are elected by three methods. Members of the National Assembly are limited to two four-year terms, regardless if they are consecutive or not.<ref name="IJBs7"/> There are gender quotas for the party lists, meaning there is Zipper system|alternation between men and women. There are no quotas for minority representation.<ref name="PDBA"/>

references.text: <ref name="PDBA"/> Fifteen are elected by closed list proportional representation in a nationwide constituency.<ref name="57lkF"/> Six are elected by overseas voters (two each from Canada/United States, Latin America/Caribbean/Africa and Asia/Europe/Oceania).<ref name="57lkF"/> The remaining 116 members are elected from multi-member constituencies by closed list proportional representation, with all seats allocated using the Webster/Sainte-Laguë method|Webster method.<ref name="57lkF">{{Cite web|title=La Asamblea aprobó reformas al Código de la Democracia|url=http://www.elcomercio.com/actualidad/reformas-elecciones-asamblea-codigo-democracia.html|access-date=15 January 2021|website=El Comercio| archive-date = 28 January 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210128084532/https://www.elcomercio.com/actualidad/reformas-elecciones-asamblea-codigo-democracia.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

A day after the dissolution of the National Assembly on 17 May 2023, former Vice President of Ecuador|Vice President Otto Sonnenholzner announced his candidacy for the presidency, with his campaign being endorsed by Actuemos Alliance and the Democratic Left (Ecuador)|Democratic Left Party. however, the party declined to nominate a candidate and instead endorsed businessman Jan Topić's candidacy on 21 May.<ref name=psc/>

references.text: <ref name=Otto/> That same day, former National Assembly member and journalist Fernando Villavicencio announced his campaign with the support of the Movimiento Construye Party.<ref name=Fernando/> On 19 May, President Lasso announced in an interview with ''The Washington Post'' that he would not run in the 2023 election.<ref name=not/><ref name=stand/> Former Mayor of Guayaquil and 1992 Ecuadorian general election|1992 and 1996 Ecuadorian general election|1996 presidential candidate Jaime Nebot expressed interest in running under the Social Christian Party (Ecuador)|Social Christian Party;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.emol.com/noticias/Internacional/2023/05/20/1095615/crisis-ecuador-candidatos-reemplazante-lasso.html|title=Crisis en Ecuador: Los candidatos que asoman para competir en la elección presidencial y reemplazar a Lasso|date=20 May 2023|publisher=EMOL|accessdate=22 May 2023|archive-date=22 May 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230522142215/https://www.emol.com/noticias/Internacional/2023/05/20/1095615/crisis-ecuador-candidatos-reemplazante-lasso.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vistazo.com/politica/nacional/estos-son-los-posibles-candidatos-a-presidente-del-ecuador-hay-exasambleistas-entre-las-opciones-YE5161346|title=Estos son los posibles candidatos a presidente del Ecuador: hay exasambleístas entre las opciones|publisher=Vistazo|accessdate=22 May 2023|archive-date=22 May 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230522142218/https://www.vistazo.com/politica/nacional/estos-son-los-posibles-candidatos-a-presidente-del-ecuador-hay-exasambleistas-entre-las-opciones-YE5161346|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 6 June, President Lasso's party Creating Opportunities announced that they would not endorse a presidential candidate. On 8 June, Quito-based businessman and 2021 presidential candidate Xavier Hervas announced his candidacy and was endorsed by the RETO Movement.<ref name=Xavier/> On 10 June, the Rafael Correa-funded Citizen Revolution Movement party sought to nominate former Vice President Jorge Glas as their nominee; Glas declined the nomination, however.<ref name=Glas/> 2021 presidential runner-up Andrés Arauz also declined to run and instead sought the vice presidential candidacy.<ref name=":0"/> The party instead nominated former Assemblywoman Luisa González as its presidential nominee and Arauz as her running mate.<ref name=":0"/>

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.teleamazonas.com/creo-no-presentara-candidatos-presidencia-asamblea/|title=CREO no presentará candidatos a la Presidencia ni a la Asamblea|accessdate=2023-06-15|date=2023-06-06|publisher=Teleamazonas|language=es|archive-date=23 June 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230623184643/https://www.teleamazonas.com/creo-no-presentara-candidatos-presidencia-asamblea/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 13 July 2023, the National Electoral Council (CNE) officially confirmed the eight candidacies of Armijos, González, Hervas, Noboa Azín, Pérez Guartambel, Sonnenholzner, Topić and Villavicencio. The CNE also said that the official campaign period would run from 13 July until 20 August.<ref name=CTEcon/>

sentences.text: On 20 August, Luisa González advanced to the run-off election after finishing in first place, winning 33% of the vote. She was noted by commentators as a protege to former President Rafael Correa. His debate performance days before the election was seen as a key factor in his second place finish. Violence, political stability and the assassination of Fernando Villavicencio were heavily noted a key factors for voters.

references.text: <ref name=reutersresults/> Her first place finish was predicted.<ref name=CNN>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/videos/world/2023/08/21/exp-ecuador-election-luisa-gonzalez-daniel-noboa-runoff-rafael-romo-lklv-082101aseg1-cnni-world.cnn|title=Luisa Gonzalez will face Daniel Noboa in Ecuador's presidential runoff election|date=21 August 2023|publisher=CNN|accessdate=21 August 2023|archive-date=21 August 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230821145247/https://www.cnn.com/videos/world/2023/08/21/exp-ecuador-election-luisa-gonzalez-daniel-noboa-runoff-rafael-romo-lklv-082101aseg1-cnni-world.cnn|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name=reutersresults/> Also advancing to the run-off was businessman Daniel Noboa, whose second place finish was seen as a surprise as his polling numbers were low in the days before the election.<ref name=WaPo>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/08/21/ecuador-presidential-election-candidate-killed/2e6d37e6-3fe4-11ee-9677-53cc50eb3f77_story.html|title=A presidential runoff is likely in Ecuador between an ally of ex-president and a banana tycoon's son|newspaper=The Washington Post|accessdate=21 August 2023|archive-date=25 August 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230825191703/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/08/21/ecuador-presidential-election-candidate-killed/2e6d37e6-3fe4-11ee-9677-53cc50eb3f77_story.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name=aol>{{cite web|url=https://www.aol.com/news/factbox-ecuadors-gonzalez-noboa-second-035037573.html|title=Factbox-Ecuador's Gonzalez and Noboa go to second round in presidential vote|date=21 August 2023|publisher=AOL|accessdate=21 August 2023|archive-date=21 August 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230821145808/https://www.aol.com/news/factbox-ecuadors-gonzalez-noboa-second-035037573.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name=WaPo/> If González would have been elected, she would have been the first woman to be elected president.<ref name="Daniel-Luisa" /> In contrast, if Noboa was elected, he would be the youngest president in Ecuador's history, at 35 years old when he took office.<ref name="Daniel-Luisa">{{Cite web|url=https://www.eluniverso.com/noticias/politica/segunda-vuelta-2023-ecuador-tendra-a-la-primera-mujer-presidenta-electa-en-las-urnas-o-al-presidente-mas-joven-de-la-historia-nota/|title=Segunda vuelta 2023: Ecuador tendrá a la primera mujer presidenta electa en las urnas o al presidente más joven de la historia|accessdate=9 October 2023|date=20 August 2023|publisher=El Universo|language=es|archive-date=11 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231011220214/https://www.eluniverso.com/noticias/politica/segunda-vuelta-2023-ecuador-tendra-a-la-primera-mujer-presidenta-electa-en-las-urnas-o-al-presidente-mas-joven-de-la-historia-nota/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: In the National Assembly (Ecuador)|National Assembly, the Citizen Revolution Movement won the most votes, coming in the first place at nearly 40% of the popular vote. Also on the ballot were votes on a 2023 Ecuadorian Yasuní National Park oil exploitation referendum|referendum on Yasuní National Park#Oil reserves|oil exploitation in the Yasuní National Park and a local one on metallic mining in the Chocó Andino.

references.text: <ref name=reutersresults/> In second place, Villavicencio's Movimiento Construye won 20% of the popular vote.<ref name=reutersresults>{{cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/world/ecuador-candidate-backed-by-correa-will-face-banana-heir-in-second-round/ar-AA1fxUKk|title=Ecuador candidate backed by Correa will face banana heir in second round|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=21 August 2023|archive-date=16 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231016054528/https://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/world/ecuador-candidate-backed-by-correa-will-face-banana-heir-in-second-round/ar-AA1fxUKk|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name=refone/><ref name=reftwo/> Voters voted to approve both measures, banning both oil exploitation in the Yasuní National Park, and metallic mining in the Chocó Andino.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://elecciones2023.cne.gob.ec/Consultas/choco|title=Consulta Popular Chocó Andino / Pichincha / Quito|publisher=CNE|accessdate=21 August 2023|archive-date=20 August 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230820222121/https://elecciones2023.cne.gob.ec/Consultas/choco|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: During the first round of the election, the overseas votes had several complications and a final count could not be established. CNE President Diana Atamaint said that the delay in counting the oversea ballots were attributed to "cyber attacks" and that new security measures were being implemented to deter further attacks. Demonstrations were held both outside the CNE headquarters in Quito and in several cities abroad, demanding a repeat vote. As a result, on 25 August, the CNE decided to annul the results of the oversea ballots, ordering a repeat of the legislative votes on the day of the runoff.

references.text: <ref name=repeat/> Several citizens{{who|date=October 2023}} criticized the delay in counting overseas ballots with the Organization of American States vowing to assist in addressing the problem.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lahora.com.ec/pais/oea-voto-telematico-extranjeros-ecuador-votaciones-anticipadas/|title=La OEA exhortó al CNE a solucionar "de manera expedita" los problemas en el voto telemático|publisher=La Hora|accessdate=11 September 2023|language=Spanish|archive-date=25 August 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230825033816/https://www.lahora.com.ec/pais/oea-voto-telematico-extranjeros-ecuador-votaciones-anticipadas/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: González, the runner-up in the second round of the presidential election, conceded to Noboa, saying "the candidate they [Noboa's voters] chose has won and as Ecuadoreans we also embrace them". At age 35, Noboa became the youngest person elected to the presidency. He vowed "to return peace to the country, to give education to the youth again, to be able to provide employment to the many people who are looking for it".<ref name=vow/>

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|last1=Glatsky|first1=Genevieve|title=Daniel Noboa, Scion of a Banana Empire, Wins Ecuador's Presidency|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/15/world/americas/ecuador-election-president.html|work=The New York Times|date=15 October 2023 |access-date=15 October 2023|archive-date=15 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231015092119/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/15/world/americas/ecuador-election-president.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name=youngest/> Following his victory, Noboa thanked voters for believing in "a new political project, a young political project, an improbable political project".<ref name=vow>{{cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/daniel-noboa-political-neophyte-and-heir-to-banana-empire-elected-president-in-ecuador/ar-AA1ihIOr|title=Daniel Noboa, political neophyte and heir to banana empire, elected president in Ecuador|publisher=MSN|accessdate=16 October 2023|archive-date=17 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231017102232/https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/daniel-noboa-political-neophyte-and-heir-to-banana-empire-elected-president-in-ecuador/ar-AA1ihIOr|url-status=live}}</ref>
